body: And earth also still does revolve around the sun and spins and moves at the same time. This sounds complicated and contradictory but the explanation is simple. For any kind of movement you need a point of reference. Obviously that point will always be stationary with everything else moving in comparison to it. If that's the sun, then earth revolves around the sun and rotates, as does everything. However if it's earth, then the sun revolves around earth, as does everything. One isn't any more correct than the other, technically they're both true depending on what your point of reference is. The main star is simply the most logical choice because it's central to nearly all solar systems, and it's the simplest model with which to explain gravity and different forces that the star plays a major role in for all objects in the solar system. This is why we don't feel the earth spinning or moving through space, because our point of reference is ourselves, who are on earth, and therefore from our perspective the earth is geocentric. But if we were on the sun, it would be solarcentric. When you get on a merry-go-round, it doesn't move at all, the world around it does and you can only tell it's the merry-go-round that's moving because of wind and air resistance. But when you're in the outside world the merry-go-round moves and the world stays the same. There's no grand central point of space we're comparing anything to absolutely, it all depends on perspective, and we've chosen the sun because it's the best one to use for science.
body_html: And earth also still does revolve around the sun and spins and moves at the same time. This sounds complicated and contradictory but the explanation is simple. For any kind of movement you need a point of reference. Obviously that point will always be stationary with everything else moving in comparison to it. If that's the sun, then earth revolves around the sun and rotates, as does everything. However if it's earth, then the sun revolves around earth, as does everything. One isn't any more correct than the other, technically they're both true depending on what your point of reference is. The main star is simply the most logical choice because it's central to nearly all solar systems, and it's the simplest model with which to explain gravity and different forces that the star plays a major role in for all objects in the solar system. This is why we don't feel the earth spinning or moving through space, because our point of reference is ourselves, who are on earth, and therefore from our perspective the earth is geocentric. But if we were on the sun, it would be solarcentric. When you get on a merry-go-round, it doesn't move at all, the world around it does and you can only tell it's the merry-go-round that's moving because of wind and air resistance. But when you're in the outside world the merry-go-round moves and the world stays the same. There's no grand central point of space we're comparing anything to absolutely, it all depends on perspective, and we've chosen the sun because it's the best one to use for science.

body:
Me either, and this isn't my idea. I just thought it'd be funny to prove almost everyone wrong.

But the "simple" explanation is, if you're in a car, you know from being outside that cars move, but observe that from inside the car, it is actually the world zooming past *you*; otherwise the movement would push you against the seat the same way someone outside getting hit with the car would, but instead you don't move or even feel the pressure to slide back. And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary. But standing on the outside, it's clear that the car is the one moving, with the exact same test! Majority seems to rule and you accept that this is just an illusion, but it's actually not. It's simply two different perspectives. Any point you select to compare movement against will always be in the center, fixed and stationary, because it's literally your point of comparison. In fact, in programming when rendering 3D worlds you do not have any "camera" to move around, as it's always on screen; instead you *move the world itself*. The same applies to the earth and the sun. This is why we don't feel the earth moving or get thrown off of it, because from our own point of reference it's not moving at all. But if you stand on the sun, earth is moving around it and rotating.

But, the sun is the most convenient place to choose since it's the largest mass and therefore the ultimate driver of gravity and other forces for everything else in the solar system. So choosing the earth or anything else is indeed odd and doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it isn't *wrong*.

Sorry but that's the simplest I could explain it with my limited male vocabulary. But motion *is* relative, and it's why scientists can't exactly determine how much earth (or anything) moves in the universe, as they don't really have a master object to pinpoint for the whole universe and compare us to. The lack of this proves motion is relative. Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary. Indeed, on its own it is stationary. In this article scientists were able to get a measurement of motion but had to resort to comparing us against what they believe to be the big bang, because there is no universal point of reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/startswithabang/2016/04/01/how-fast-does-earth-move-through-the-universe/
body_html:
Me either, and this isn't my idea. I just thought it'd be funny to prove almost everyone wrong.

But the "simple" explanation is, if you're in a car, you know from being outside that cars move, but observe that from inside the car, it is actually the world zooming past you; otherwise the movement would push you against the seat the same way someone outside getting hit with the car would, but instead you don't move or even feel the pressure to slide back. And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary. But standing on the outside, it's clear that the car is the one moving, with the exact same test! Majority seems to rule and you accept that this is just an illusion, but it's actually not. It's simply two different perspectives. Any point you select to compare movement against will always be in the center, fixed and stationary, because it's literally your point of comparison. In fact, in programming when rendering 3D worlds you do not have any "camera" to move around, as it's always on screen; instead you move the world itself. The same applies to the earth and the sun. This is why we don't feel the earth moving or get thrown off of it, because from our own point of reference it's not moving at all. But if you stand on the sun, earth is moving around it and rotating.

But, the sun is the most convenient place to choose since it's the largest mass and therefore the ultimate driver of gravity and other forces for everything else in the solar system. So choosing the earth or anything else is indeed odd and doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it isn't wrong.

Sorry but that's the simplest I could explain it with my limited male vocabulary. But motion is relative, and it's why scientists can't exactly determine how much earth (or anything) moves in the universe, as they don't really have a master object to pinpoint for the whole universe and compare us to. The lack of this proves motion is relative. Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary. Indeed, on its own it is stationary. In this article scientists were able to get a measurement of motion but had to resort to comparing us against what they believe to be the big bang, because there is no universal point of reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/startswithabang/2016/04/01/how-fast-does-earth-move-through-the-universe/

author.bio: god, what a bad run this site was.
author.bio_html: god, what a bad run this site was.

body:
> Me either, and this isn't my idea. I just thought it'd be funny to prove almost everyone wrong.

you're not proving anyone wrong though

> But the "simple" explanation is, if you're in a car, you know from being outside that cars move, but observe that from inside the car, it is actually the world zooming past you; otherwise the movement would push you against the seat the same way someone outside getting hit with the car would, but instead you don't move or even feel the pressure to slide back

Humans dont feel movement. The thing we're able to feel is acceleration, that's why we feel different when the car is accelerating (+-) compared to when the speed is constant. It's the same thing with our inner ear being able to hear which way is down because of gravity. When we are in a moving car, we are moving at almost the same rate as the car, i.e. the relative speed between us and the car would be around 0. 

The car brought us up to that speed, and if it were to abruptly stop we would find ourselves being flung forward because we would not have slowed down, only the car.

>  it is actually the world zooming past you

this is philosophy, not scientific.

> And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary

short answer: no. 

go ahead, get inside the car with your favourite drink, feel yourself being accelerated. When you reach a constant speed, spill your favourite drink between the front seats and see it fly back to the back seats. When the liquid is in the cup it has potential energy, when you pour it out it has kinetic energy. but only at the spot you poured it out on. It itself has not been affected by the cars movement. It moves in the direction of gravity, it's not trying to behave like a pet and obey your orders of it having to be spilled out underneath the cup.

> And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary

If we're going to play the gender game like you do later on in your text, then sure. My feeble female brain cannot understand what you're trying to prove here. 

> Majority seems to rule and you accept that this is just an illusion, but it's actually not. It's simply two different perspectives.

Majority? Maybe there is something to it then if it's the majority rule. Just as theres something to the "bluepill" if everyone you met told you the same exact things. X. 

The reason we find cars to be moving when we're walking on the pavement outside is because we are moving at a slower speed than them. The the same thing when we find other cars being stationary on the road when in reality they're just moving at a slower rate than our vehicle. 

> Any point you select to compare movement against will always be in the center, fixed and stationary, because it's literally your point of comparison.

How about I tell you that nothing is fixed and stationary. Galaxies roam, love. We perceive it as such because we are moving at the same speed the object is. And we're moving at the same speed the earth is. My IKEA wardrobe seems to be stationary but it is moving the same speed as the Earth. It doesnt matter what perspective we see it from. If my wardrobe was the centre, how come the Milky Way isn't orbiting around it?

> In fact, in programming when rendering 3D worlds you do not have any "camera" to move around, as it's always on screen; instead you move the world itself. The same applies to the earth and the sun. This is why we don't feel the earth moving or get thrown off of it, because from our own point of reference it's not moving at all.

On the contrary, when I am using CAD I am moving the camera around the object(s). They're stationary on a plane. If I moved them, then the measurement plane would have to move as well, using a lot more of the computer's power which is unessecary.

>  But if you stand on the sun, earth is moving around it and rotating.

First off, I was standing on the sun I would be dead, even if I stood on a coldspot.

The reason I would perceive it as such is because it *is*. If I stood at the centre of the Milky Way, I would perceive the sun to be rotating around that point, because it *is*. The largest mass has the largest gravitational pull, that happens to be our star. If a larger star would fly past our solar system, or even a star with the same mass but moving closer to us, the Earth would be flung out of orbit and our planet would become roaming. We would no longer be orbiting a big mass like the sun. 

We would also feel the Earth accelerating with the force of this new star.

> But, the sun is the most convenient place to choose since it's the largest mass and therefore the ultimate driver of gravity and other forces for everything else in the solar system. So choosing the earth or anything else is indeed odd and doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it isn't *wrong*.

Indeed it is not wrong, however the thought is not complete, and can't be taken seriously as a result. We know the Earth is moving, and if we observe where its moving then we get an oval around the sun. Same thing with the sun, only on a much much bigger scale around the Milky Way. It also orbits along with Jupiter as the planet is only 1 000 times smaller than the sun. As such it doesnt orbit the sun, it orbits a point between the sun and Jupiter called the barycentre. This affects both Jupiter and the sun. interesting, right!

> Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary.

because we are moving, and they are moving. When we are driving, we see cars moving at different paces outside. Sometimes even zooming past. everything is moving and cannot accelerate without an outside force. The reason we dont see everything that is zooming past in is *because* our vision is not that good, our vision gets blocked by our atmosphere. There are different factors, like light pollution and light itself that hinders us from seeing all the coolness of space.
body_html:
Me either, and this isn't my idea. I just thought it'd be funny to prove almost everyone wrong.

you're not proving anyone wrong though

But the "simple" explanation is, if you're in a car, you know from being outside that cars move, but observe that from inside the car, it is actually the world zooming past you; otherwise the movement would push you against the seat the same way someone outside getting hit with the car would, but instead you don't move or even feel the pressure to slide back

Humans dont feel movement. The thing we're able to feel is acceleration, that's why we feel different when the car is accelerating (+-) compared to when the speed is constant. It's the same thing with our inner ear being able to hear which way is down because of gravity. When we are in a moving car, we are moving at almost the same rate as the car, i.e. the relative speed between us and the car would be around 0.

The car brought us up to that speed, and if it were to abruptly stop we would find ourselves being flung forward because we would not have slowed down, only the car.

it is actually the world zooming past you

this is philosophy, not scientific.

And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary

short answer: no.

go ahead, get inside the car with your favourite drink, feel yourself being accelerated. When you reach a constant speed, spill your favourite drink between the front seats and see it fly back to the back seats. When the liquid is in the cup it has potential energy, when you pour it out it has kinetic energy. but only at the spot you poured it out on. It itself has not been affected by the cars movement. It moves in the direction of gravity, it's not trying to behave like a pet and obey your orders of it having to be spilled out underneath the cup.

And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary

If we're going to play the gender game like you do later on in your text, then sure. My feeble female brain cannot understand what you're trying to prove here.

Majority seems to rule and you accept that this is just an illusion, but it's actually not. It's simply two different perspectives.

Majority? Maybe there is something to it then if it's the majority rule. Just as theres something to the "bluepill" if everyone you met told you the same exact things. X.

The reason we find cars to be moving when we're walking on the pavement outside is because we are moving at a slower speed than them. The the same thing when we find other cars being stationary on the road when in reality they're just moving at a slower rate than our vehicle.

Any point you select to compare movement against will always be in the center, fixed and stationary, because it's literally your point of comparison.

How about I tell you that nothing is fixed and stationary. Galaxies roam, love. We perceive it as such because we are moving at the same speed the object is. And we're moving at the same speed the earth is. My IKEA wardrobe seems to be stationary but it is moving the same speed as the Earth. It doesnt matter what perspective we see it from. If my wardrobe was the centre, how come the Milky Way isn't orbiting around it?

In fact, in programming when rendering 3D worlds you do not have any "camera" to move around, as it's always on screen; instead you move the world itself. The same applies to the earth and the sun. This is why we don't feel the earth moving or get thrown off of it, because from our own point of reference it's not moving at all.

On the contrary, when I am using CAD I am moving the camera around the object(s). They're stationary on a plane. If I moved them, then the measurement plane would have to move as well, using a lot more of the computer's power which is unessecary.

But if you stand on the sun, earth is moving around it and rotating.

First off, I was standing on the sun I would be dead, even if I stood on a coldspot.

The reason I would perceive it as such is because it is. If I stood at the centre of the Milky Way, I would perceive the sun to be rotating around that point, because it is. The largest mass has the largest gravitational pull, that happens to be our star. If a larger star would fly past our solar system, or even a star with the same mass but moving closer to us, the Earth would be flung out of orbit and our planet would become roaming. We would no longer be orbiting a big mass like the sun.

We would also feel the Earth accelerating with the force of this new star.

But, the sun is the most convenient place to choose since it's the largest mass and therefore the ultimate driver of gravity and other forces for everything else in the solar system. So choosing the earth or anything else is indeed odd and doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it isn't wrong.

Indeed it is not wrong, however the thought is not complete, and can't be taken seriously as a result. We know the Earth is moving, and if we observe where its moving then we get an oval around the sun. Same thing with the sun, only on a much much bigger scale around the Milky Way. It also orbits along with Jupiter as the planet is only 1 000 times smaller than the sun. As such it doesnt orbit the sun, it orbits a point between the sun and Jupiter called the barycentre. This affects both Jupiter and the sun. interesting, right!

Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary.

because we are moving, and they are moving. When we are driving, we see cars moving at different paces outside. Sometimes even zooming past. everything is moving and cannot accelerate without an outside force. The reason we dont see everything that is zooming past in is because our vision is not that good, our vision gets blocked by our atmosphere. There are different factors, like light pollution and light itself that hinders us from seeing all the coolness of space.

guild.description: Got a burning unpopular opinion you want to share? Spark some discussions!
guild.description_html: Got a burning unpopular opinion you want to share? Spark some discussions!
guild.name: UnpopularOpinion

parent.body:
Me either, and this isn't my idea. I just thought it'd be funny to prove almost everyone wrong.

But the "simple" explanation is, if you're in a car, you know from being outside that cars move, but observe that from inside the car, it is actually the world zooming past *you*; otherwise the movement would push you against the seat the same way someone outside getting hit with the car would, but instead you don't move or even feel the pressure to slide back. And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary. But standing on the outside, it's clear that the car is the one moving, with the exact same test! Majority seems to rule and you accept that this is just an illusion, but it's actually not. It's simply two different perspectives. Any point you select to compare movement against will always be in the center, fixed and stationary, because it's literally your point of comparison. In fact, in programming when rendering 3D worlds you do not have any "camera" to move around, as it's always on screen; instead you *move the world itself*. The same applies to the earth and the sun. This is why we don't feel the earth moving or get thrown off of it, because from our own point of reference it's not moving at all. But if you stand on the sun, earth is moving around it and rotating.

But, the sun is the most convenient place to choose since it's the largest mass and therefore the ultimate driver of gravity and other forces for everything else in the solar system. So choosing the earth or anything else is indeed odd and doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it isn't *wrong*.

Sorry but that's the simplest I could explain it with my limited male vocabulary. But motion *is* relative, and it's why scientists can't exactly determine how much earth (or anything) moves in the universe, as they don't really have a master object to pinpoint for the whole universe and compare us to. The lack of this proves motion is relative. Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary. Indeed, on its own it is stationary. In this article scientists were able to get a measurement of motion but had to resort to comparing us against what they believe to be the big bang, because there is no universal point of reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/startswithabang/2016/04/01/how-fast-does-earth-move-through-the-universe/
parent.body_html:
Me either, and this isn't my idea. I just thought it'd be funny to prove almost everyone wrong.

But the "simple" explanation is, if you're in a car, you know from being outside that cars move, but observe that from inside the car, it is actually the world zooming past you; otherwise the movement would push you against the seat the same way someone outside getting hit with the car would, but instead you don't move or even feel the pressure to slide back. And even spills and dust and feathers fall straight down inside, proving that it is the world around you moving and the car remains stationary. But standing on the outside, it's clear that the car is the one moving, with the exact same test! Majority seems to rule and you accept that this is just an illusion, but it's actually not. It's simply two different perspectives. Any point you select to compare movement against will always be in the center, fixed and stationary, because it's literally your point of comparison. In fact, in programming when rendering 3D worlds you do not have any "camera" to move around, as it's always on screen; instead you move the world itself. The same applies to the earth and the sun. This is why we don't feel the earth moving or get thrown off of it, because from our own point of reference it's not moving at all. But if you stand on the sun, earth is moving around it and rotating.

But, the sun is the most convenient place to choose since it's the largest mass and therefore the ultimate driver of gravity and other forces for everything else in the solar system. So choosing the earth or anything else is indeed odd and doesn't make a whole lot of sense, but it isn't wrong.

Sorry but that's the simplest I could explain it with my limited male vocabulary. But motion is relative, and it's why scientists can't exactly determine how much earth (or anything) moves in the universe, as they don't really have a master object to pinpoint for the whole universe and compare us to. The lack of this proves motion is relative. Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary. Indeed, on its own it is stationary. In this article scientists were able to get a measurement of motion but had to resort to comparing us against what they believe to be the big bang, because there is no universal point of reference: https://www.forbes.com/sites/startswithabang/2016/04/01/how-fast-does-earth-move-through-the-universe/

post.body: And earth also still does revolve around the sun and spins and moves at the same time. This sounds complicated and contradictory but the explanation is simple. For any kind of movement you need a point of reference. Obviously that point will always be stationary with everything else moving in comparison to it. If that's the sun, then earth revolves around the sun and rotates, as does everything. However if it's earth, then the sun revolves around earth, as does everything. One isn't any more correct than the other, technically they're both true depending on what your point of reference is. The main star is simply the most logical choice because it's central to nearly all solar systems, and it's the simplest model with which to explain gravity and different forces that the star plays a major role in for all objects in the solar system. This is why we don't feel the earth spinning or moving through space, because our point of reference is ourselves, who are on earth, and therefore from our perspective the earth is geocentric. But if we were on the sun, it would be solarcentric. When you get on a merry-go-round, it doesn't move at all, the world around it does and you can only tell it's the merry-go-round that's moving because of wind and air resistance. But when you're in the outside world the merry-go-round moves and the world stays the same. There's no grand central point of space we're comparing anything to absolutely, it all depends on perspective, and we've chosen the sun because it's the best one to use for science.
post.body_html: And earth also still does revolve around the sun and spins and moves at the same time. This sounds complicated and contradictory but the explanation is simple. For any kind of movement you need a point of reference. Obviously that point will always be stationary with everything else moving in comparison to it. If that's the sun, then earth revolves around the sun and rotates, as does everything. However if it's earth, then the sun revolves around earth, as does everything. One isn't any more correct than the other, technically they're both true depending on what your point of reference is. The main star is simply the most logical choice because it's central to nearly all solar systems, and it's the simplest model with which to explain gravity and different forces that the star plays a major role in for all objects in the solar system. This is why we don't feel the earth spinning or moving through space, because our point of reference is ourselves, who are on earth, and therefore from our perspective the earth is geocentric. But if we were on the sun, it would be solarcentric. When you get on a merry-go-round, it doesn't move at all, the world around it does and you can only tell it's the merry-go-round that's moving because of wind and air resistance. But when you're in the outside world the merry-go-round moves and the world stays the same. There's no grand central point of space we're comparing anything to absolutely, it all depends on perspective, and we've chosen the sun because it's the best one to use for science.
post.title: The sun and the universe really do revolve around the stationary earth

author.bio:
Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

Remember: History repeats, and the unaware are doomed to repeat it.

Goodbye. https://ruqqus.com/+The_Cabal/post/d9y9/i-told-you-so-all-the

body:
> If we're going to play the gender game like you do later on in your text, then sure. My feeble female brain cannot understand what you're trying to prove here.

Well my retarded male brain is too stupid to EVER do CAD, even though men are supposed to be better with spatial skills (I think men are better with motor spatial skills as in guessing movement and measurements in the real world, but women are still better with actually designing and reproducing them, which would include art and 3d modeling). I think you're still assuming the standard reference points for motion but not thinking in absolute terms. It's fine that you don't understand it, I only know this from prior knowledge or else I'd be as confused as you are.

> On the contrary, when I am using CAD I am moving the camera around the object(s). They're stationary on a plane. If I moved them, then the measurement plane would have to move as well, using a lot more of the computer's power which is unessecary.

The camera is a construct of the CAD program. The program actually renders the "camera" by moving the world in the opposite direction. I only know this because I've created simple 3d programs before.

> Indeed it is not wrong, however the thought is not complete, and can't be taken seriously as a result. We know the Earth is moving, and if we observe where its moving then we get an oval around the sun. Same thing with the sun, only on a much much bigger scale around the Milky Way. It also orbits along with Jupiter as the planet is only 1 000 times smaller than the sun. As such it doesnt orbit the sun, it orbits a point between the sun and Jupiter called the barycentre. This affects both Jupiter and the sun. interesting, right!

You know way more than me.
body_html:
If we're going to play the gender game like you do later on in your text, then sure. My feeble female brain cannot understand what you're trying to prove here.

Well my retarded male brain is too stupid to EVER do CAD, even though men are supposed to be better with spatial skills (I think men are better with motor spatial skills as in guessing movement and measurements in the real world, but women are still better with actually designing and reproducing them, which would include art and 3d modeling). I think you're still assuming the standard reference points for motion but not thinking in absolute terms. It's fine that you don't understand it, I only know this from prior knowledge or else I'd be as confused as you are.

On the contrary, when I am using CAD I am moving the camera around the object(s). They're stationary on a plane. If I moved them, then the measurement plane would have to move as well, using a lot more of the computer's power which is unessecary.

The camera is a construct of the CAD program. The program actually renders the "camera" by moving the world in the opposite direction. I only know this because I've created simple 3d programs before.

Indeed it is not wrong, however the thought is not complete, and can't be taken seriously as a result. We know the Earth is moving, and if we observe where its moving then we get an oval around the sun. Same thing with the sun, only on a much much bigger scale around the Milky Way. It also orbits along with Jupiter as the planet is only 1 000 times smaller than the sun. As such it doesnt orbit the sun, it orbits a point between the sun and Jupiter called the barycentre. This affects both Jupiter and the sun. interesting, right!

You know way more than me.

We know the Earth is moving, and if we observe where its moving then we get an oval around the sun. Same thing with the sun, only on a much much bigger scale around the Milky Way. It also orbits along with Jupiter as the planet is only 1 000 times smaller than the sun. As such it doesnt orbit the sun, it orbits a point between the sun and Jupiter called the barycentre. This affects both Jupiter and the sun. interesting, right!

Also the fact that earth, on top of the solar system, on top of the milky way "moves" very fast yet everything within our solar system does not fly past us, but remains completely in place as if it were stationary.

because we are moving, and they are moving. When we are driving, we see cars moving at different paces outside. Sometimes even zooming past. everything is moving and cannot accelerate without an outside force. The reason we dont see everything that is zooming past in is because our vision is not that good, our vision gets blocked by our atmosphere. There are different factors, like light pollution and light itself that hinders us from seeing all the coolness of space.

post.body: And earth also still does revolve around the sun and spins and moves at the same time. This sounds complicated and contradictory but the explanation is simple. For any kind of movement you need a point of reference. Obviously that point will always be stationary with everything else moving in comparison to it. If that's the sun, then earth revolves around the sun and rotates, as does everything. However if it's earth, then the sun revolves around earth, as does everything. One isn't any more correct than the other, technically they're both true depending on what your point of reference is. The main star is simply the most logical choice because it's central to nearly all solar systems, and it's the simplest model with which to explain gravity and different forces that the star plays a major role in for all objects in the solar system. This is why we don't feel the earth spinning or moving through space, because our point of reference is ourselves, who are on earth, and therefore from our perspective the earth is geocentric. But if we were on the sun, it would be solarcentric. When you get on a merry-go-round, it doesn't move at all, the world around it does and you can only tell it's the merry-go-round that's moving because of wind and air resistance. But when you're in the outside world the merry-go-round moves and the world stays the same. There's no grand central point of space we're comparing anything to absolutely, it all depends on perspective, and we've chosen the sun because it's the best one to use for science.

post.title: The sun and the universe really do revolve around the stationary earth
